questions.text: 1. A 45-year-old man with abnormal gait and hearing problems presents with a cerebellopontine mass. Histopathological examination demonstrates Antony A and Antony B areas with Verocay bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological examination of a cerebellopontine mass showing Antony A and Antony B areas with Verocay bodies points to a diagnosis of Schwannoma.

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it. They are commonly associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22q12.

Microscopically, it consists of dense areas called Antoni A and loose areas called Antoni B.

* The Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with nuclear-free zones between them, forming structures called Verocay bodies.

* The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged and separated by prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

The image below shows cellular Antoni A and paucicellular Antoni B areas in schwannoma:



The image below shows verocay bodies in the Antoni-A area of vestibular schwannoma.



Other tumors arising at the cerebellopontine angle (CPA) are:

* Meningioma (the 2nd most common tumor at CPA)

* Cholesteatoma

* Arachnoid cysts

* Glomus tumor

* Metastases

Other options:

Option B: Glioblastoma shows necrotic foci surrounded by pseudopalisading malignant nuclei along with prominent endothelial proliferation.

Option C: Oligodendroglioma shows the classic “fried‑egg” appearance with round nuclei surrounded by clear perinuclear halos and a delicate “chicken‑wire” capillary network.

Option D: Medulloblastoma shows sheets of small-round, blue cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, frequently forming Homer‑Wright rosettes.

Pearl PM2482: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

* Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas

* Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 

* Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions

* Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 



 

Medulloblastoma:

* Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells

* Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped

* Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil



 

Ependymoma:

* Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 

* Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel



 

Oligodendroglioma:

* Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 

* Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries



 

Retinoblastoma: 

* Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei

* Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen

* Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center

* Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.



Pearl PM1740: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Halberstaedter–Prowazek bodies

 Trachoma 
Miyagawa bodies Lymphogranuloma venereum 
Levinthal–Cole–Lillie bodies Psittacosis
Leishman–Donovan bodies Kala-azar 
Negri bodies Rabies
Guarnieri bodies Vaccinia
Bollinger bodies Fowl pox
Henderson–Paterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum 
Cowdry type-A bodies Yellow fever, Herpes virus infection 
Cowdry type-B bodies Adenovirus, poliovirus
Rusell bodies Multiple myeloma 
Aschoff bodies Rheumatic fever 
Call–Exner bodies Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary 
Civatte (colloid) bodies Lichen planus 
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies Malakoplakia 
Lewy bodies Parkinson's disease 
Pappenheimer bodies Non-heme iron pigments in siderocytes 
Howell–Jolly bodies Splenectomy, Megaloblastic Anemia, Hemolytic anemia 
Heinz bodies G-6-PD deficiency 
Gamna–Gandy bodies Congestive splenomegaly 
Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis
Councilman bodies Hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis, seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.
Psammoma bodies Dystrophic calcification in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenoma of ovary & papillary carcinoma of thyroid, papillary type of renal cell carcinoma.
Donovan bodies Granuloma inguinale 
Nissl's bodies Cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons 
Mooser bodies Typhus fever
Creola bodies Asthma 
Verocay bodies Schwannoma 
Schiller–Duval bodies Endodermal sinus tumor 

Hirano bodies

  Alzheimer’s disease

Ferruginous bodies

 Asbestosis

questions.text:
2. A 33-year-old man presents with a testicular bulky mass which was homogenous, grey-white and lobulated on the cut surface. It did not show hemorrhage or necrosis. Microscopic H&E image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?

H&E - Hematoxylin and Eosin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the H&E image, points to a diagnosis of Seminoma.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (GCT). The peak incidence is in the 3rd decade and almost never occurs in infants. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT (regardless of KIT mutational status), OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that bulges around the surrounding parenchyma and does not show hemorrhage or necrosis. The image given below shows the gross cut-section of seminoma.



The H&E image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance), delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. This is characteristic of seminoma or seminomatous germ-cell tumor.



Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP) are the tumor markers that may be raised in a case of seminoma.

Testicular biopsy is contraindicated in case of a suspicious testicular mass because it is associated with a risk of tumor cell spillage. High inguinal orchidectomy followed by histopathological evaluation is the preferred standard management. The fixative used for testicular biopsy is Bouin's fluid.

Other options:

Option B:  Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.  Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary folds.



Option C: Yolk sac tumor is non-encapsulated with a mucinous appearance. Schiller–Duval bodies are characteristic. It is seen in children less than 3 years. Schiller–Duval body is shown in the image below.



Option D: Testicular lymphoma is a rare extranodal presentation of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common testicular lymphoma, and the histopathological slide showing large lymphoma cells infiltrating between the seminiferous tubules is given below. Later, the lymphoma cells may infiltrate the seminiferous tubules. Necrosis can be seen commonly.



Pearl PM2277: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Seminoma

* Non-seminomatous GCTs

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type

* Choriocarcinoma

* Teratoma, post-pubertal type

* Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Spermatocytic tumour

* Teratoma, prepubertal type

* Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type

* Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

* Leydig cell tumor

* Sertoli cell tumor

* Granulosa cell tumor

* Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

* Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Pearl PM2279: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor


AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

questions.text:
3. A 28-year-old female presents with multiple cervical lymphadenopathies. IHC markers were positive for CD10 and BCL-2. Peripheral smear shows a large number of small cells (centrocytes) and occasional large cells (centroblasts). What is the most common genetic defect in this condition?

IHC - Immunohistochemistry
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features, along with the IHC findings, are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. The majority of follicular lymphomas have the characteristic t(14;18) BCL2-IGH translocation.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center.

Follicular lymphoma results from a chromosomal rearrangement, t(14;18) BCL2-IGH, which is the translocation of the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the immunoglobulin heavy chain locus (IGH) on chromosome 14, resulting in the overexpression of the BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

On histopathology, the lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions (in most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes): 

* Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm

* Centroblasts - large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

The following image shows the histopathological findings of follicular lymphoma, along with strong IHC positivity for BCL-2 in the follicular centre B-cells, a feature that is typically present in mantle zone cells.



Other options:

Option B: t(11;18) MALT1 is seen in MALT (Muocsal-Associated Lymphoid Tissue) Lymphoma

Option C: t(2;5) ALK is seen in Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma.

Option D: t(11;14) Cyclin D1-IGH is seen in mantle cell lymphoma.

Pearl PM0261: Malignancies, Translocations and Affected Genes

Malignancy

Translocation

Affected Genes

t(14;19)

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML)

t(9;22)

ABL 9q34

BCR 22q11

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)

t(8; 21), t(15; 17)

AML1 21q22

ETO 8q22

PML 15q22

RARA 17q21

Precursor B cell ALL

t(9;22), t(4;11)

  

BCR/ABL

AF4, ALLI

Burkitt lymphoma

t(8; 14), t(2;8) t(8;22)

c-myc 8q24

IGH 14q32

Mantle cell lymphoma

t(11; 14)

CCND1 11q13

IGH 14q32

BCL1

Follicular lymphoma

t(14; 18)

IGH 14q32

BCL2 18q21

 

Ewing sarcoma

t(11; 22)

FLI1 11q24

EWSR1 22q12

Prostatic adenocarcinoma

t(7; 21), t(17; 21)

TMPRSS2 (21q22.3)

ETV1 (7p21.2)

ETV4 (17q21)

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

  t(14;18)  

BCL-6, p53

MALT lymphoma

 t(11;18) API2/MALT, BCL-10

CD30+ Anaplastic large cell lymphoma

Lymphoplasmacytoid lymphoma

Synovial sarcoma

SS18-SSX2

SS18-SSX4
 Alveolar soft-part sarcoma  t(X;17)(p11.2;q25)  TFE3-ASPL

questions.text:
4. In a patient, ileal resection led to fatigue with Hb = 8 g/dL, MCV = 110 fL. Peripheral smear showed macrocytic anemia. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely?

Hb - Hemoglobin MCV - Mean Corpuscular Volume
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, given the history of ileal resection, macrocytosis, and low hemoglobin level.

Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate. The ileum is the site of vitamin B12 absorption; hence, ileal resection predisposes the patient to develop a vitamin B12 deficiency.

In vitamin B12 deficiency, laboratory findings typically show reduced hemoglobin, indicating anemia, raised mean corpuscular volume (MCV), indicating macrocytosis (>100 fL), increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH), normal mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), elevated red cell distribution width (RDW), and decreased reticulocyte count. Both homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels are elevated.

Vitamin B12 deficiency commonly presents with fatigue, glossitis, and angular cheilosis. Gastrointestinal symptoms such as anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation may occur. Hematologically, patients often show ineffective erythropoiesis leading to anemia, sometimes with mild jaundice. Neurological manifestations, including peripheral neuropathy and paresthesias, are also characteristic of B12 deficiency.

The peripheral smear shows macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils, as shown in the image below.



Other options:

Option A: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by a low hemoglobin level and microcytic anemia (low MCV). Iron is essential for hemoglobin synthesis, and its deficiency leads to reduced hemoglobin levels. Iron is absorbed primarily in the duodenum.

Option C: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is mainly associated with neurological syndromes such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. It can be associated with thiamine-responsive megaloblastic anemia. Thiamine is absorbed in the proximal small intestine.

Option D: Folate deficiency is a common cause of megaloblastic anemia, but folate is absorbed in the proximal jejunum; hence, its deficiency is less likely after ileal resection in this patient’s condition.

questions.text: 5. A young lady presents with jaundice and pruritus. She is antimitochondrial antibody positive and ANA negative. Biopsy shows portal inflammation and ductular proliferation with lymphocytic infiltrate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with the biopsy findings, point to a diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC).

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is a chronic autoimmune liver disease characterized by the chronic, non-suppurative inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It is commonly seen in women aged 40-50 years. 

Most of the patients are asymptomatic; symptomatic patients present with fatigue out of proportion to the extent of liver disease or the age of the patient. Pruritus is another common complaint. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease, such as hepatosplenomegaly and ascites, may be seen, but may not be common. 

Laboratory findings show a cholestatic pattern of liver enzyme elevation, with increased levels of GGT and ALP. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are present in most patients with PBC. A liver biopsy is relevant in the setting of AMA-negative disease and would demonstrate florid duct lesions/ granulomas (shown in the image below).



Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line treatment early in the disease course. It has been shown to slow the progress of the disease. Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for patients with decompensated liver disease due to PBC. Seladelpar and Elafibranor are newly approved drugs to treat PBC.

Other options:

Option B: Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the biliary tree. They are more common in females and are typically diagnosed in childhood. The most common form shows fusiform dilatation of the bile duct.

Option C: Autoimmune Hepatitis may present with fatigue, pruritus, ↑ AST, and ↑ ALT. It is often positive for anti-smooth muscle antibodies.

Option D: Focal Nodular Hyperplasia is a tumor of the liver commonly seen in young women. It shows a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar. On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout.

Pearl PM1934: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

  Primary Biliary Cholangitis Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
Antibodies

Antimitochondrial antibodies positive in most patients

Antinuclear antibodies positive

Antimitochondrial antibodies /AMA typically negative

p-ANCA-positive
Age group 40–60 years 30-45 years
Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
 Associated with

Sjogren syndrome

Hashimoto's thyroiditis 

CREST syndrome

Rheumatoid arthritis

Celiac disease

 Ulcerative colitis
Diagnosis Biopsy MRCP/ERCP-strictures 
Biopsy findings  Florid duct lesion (granuloma) Concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis    
Long-term complication Cirrhosis

Cirrhosis

Cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: 6. A child presents with visual disturbances and delayed growth. Imaging reveals a suprasellar mass and histopathology shows the presence of "wet keratin". What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with imaging showing a suprasellar mass with histopathology showing "wet keratin," points to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has a bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Wet keratin refers to compact, lamellar keratin formation that is characteristically associated with adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma. Papillary craniopharyngioma is differentiated from adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma by the absence of lamellar keratin, calcifications, cysts, peripheral palisading of squamous cells, and a spongy reticulum.

The following is an MRI showing a suprasellar mass, as seen in craniopharyngioma.



The following histopathological image shows wet keratin along with solid and cystic components seen in the tumor.



Other options:

Option A: Gliomas, which are the most common group of primary brain tumors, include ependymoma, oligodendroglioma, and astrocytoma.

Option C: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement. Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer-Wright rosettes.

Option D: Pituitary adenomas are usually found in adults. The most common genetic alterations in this condition are mutations in ­proteins (particularly GNAS). Depending on their size, they are classified as microadenomas (diameter < 1 cm) and macroadenomas (diameter > 1 cm). They may be functioning or non-functioning. The most common type of functioning pituitary adenomas is prolactinomas.

questions.text: 7. An old man complains of fatigue. On examination, there is generalised lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the investigation that differentiates cancers based on CD markers?
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry is the investigation that differentiates based on CD markers of different cancers.

Flow cytometry is a laser-based method that analyzes cells and cell components based on the presence of certain cell surface molecules, which are named according to the cluster of differentiation (CD) nomenclature.

There are about 300 types of CD molecules. Monoclonal antibodies against specific CD molecules are tagged with fluorescent labels. Incubation of the cells with a variety of different CD-labeled antibodies allows the flow cytometric analysis of distinct populations of cells in the mixture.

Given is a dot plot obtained after performing flow cytometry. The plot is divided into 4 quadrants based on the presence or absence of antigen A & B. Each dot represents a single cell. The position of the dot expresses whether the cell expresses antigen A, antigen B, both, or neither

* Quadrant 1: Cells positive for antigen B but negative for antigen A.

* Quadrant 2: Cells negative for both antigen A and antigen B.

* Quadrant 3: Cells positive for both antigen A and antigen B.

* Quadrant 4: Cells positive for antigen A but negative for antigen B.



Other options:

Option A: Gene typing or molecular genetic tests can detect specific gene rearrangements or mutations, but do not directly differentiate cell types based on CD markers.

Option C: Bone marrow biopsy helps in identifying morphological and histological changes associated with cancers. Additional immunophenotyping tests, such as flow cytometry, are needed to differentiate cancers based on CD markers.

Option D: Cytogenetics helps in studying chromosomal abnormalities but does not analyze CD markers.

questions.text: 8. Patient presents with cough, stridor, and dyspnea. On examination, there was lymphadenopathy. Histopathological examination of the lymph node shows granulomas with giant cells and stellate concretions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as cough, dyspnea, dry eyes, and usually has bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Naked granulomas are non-caseating granulomas minimally surrounded by lymphocytes.

Star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies (stellate concretions) and laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.





Other options:

Option A: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) occurs due to inhalational exposure to a number of antigens, causing inflammation of the alveoli and the small airways. The cause of the inflammation is dysregulated Th1 and Th17 immune response (type IV hypersensitivity). Lung biopsy shows the formation of noncaseating granulomas, but they are poorly defined.

Option B: Churg-Strauss syndrome (Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) involves the skin, cardiac and gastrointestinal tract, and peripheral nervous system with associated eosinophilia. Biopsy shows necrotizing vasculitis with eosinophilic infiltrates and eosinophilic granulomas.

Option C: Tuberculosis has more constitutional symptoms with granulomas showing caseous necrosis, abundant lymphocytes, and acid-fast bacilli.

Pearl PM2355: Types of granulomas

GRANULOMA SEEN IN
Noncaseating granuloma

Crohn’s disease

Leprosy

Sarcoidosis

Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Caseating granuloma

Tuberculosis

Histoplasmosis

Syphilis

Coccidiomycosis
Foreign body granuloma

Silicosis

Berylliosis
Immune granuloma

Wegener’s granulomatosis

Giant cell arteritis
Durck’s granuloma Cerebral malaria
Stellate granuloma Cat scratch disease


Pearl PM1740: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Halberstaedter–Prowazek bodies

 Trachoma 
Miyagawa bodies Lymphogranuloma venereum 
Levinthal–Cole–Lillie bodies Psittacosis
Leishman–Donovan bodies Kala-azar 
Negri bodies Rabies
Guarnieri bodies Vaccinia
Bollinger bodies Fowl pox
Henderson–Paterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum 
Cowdry type-A bodies Yellow fever, Herpes virus infection 
Cowdry type-B bodies Adenovirus, poliovirus
Rusell bodies Multiple myeloma 
Aschoff bodies Rheumatic fever 
Call–Exner bodies Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary 
Civatte (colloid) bodies Lichen planus 
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies Malakoplakia 
Lewy bodies Parkinson's disease 
Pappenheimer bodies Non-heme iron pigments in siderocytes 
Howell–Jolly bodies Splenectomy, Megaloblastic Anemia, Hemolytic anemia 
Heinz bodies G-6-PD deficiency 
Gamna–Gandy bodies Congestive splenomegaly 
Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis
Councilman bodies Hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis, seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.

Donovan bodies Granuloma inguinale

questions.text: 9. Caspases are involved in which of the following types of programmed cell death?
questions.solution:
Caspases are involved in Pyroptosis and Apoptosis.

Pyroptosis is a form of cell death driven by the release of the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-1. When cytoplasmic innate immune receptors detect microbial components inside cells, they trigger the formation of a multiprotein complex called the inflammasome.

The inflammasome activates caspase-1, which in turn promotes the release of active IL-1. Caspases 4 and 5 can also contribute to this cell death. Unlike apoptosis, pyroptosis is marked by the release of inflammatory molecules.

Apoptosis involves both intrinsic (mitochondrial) and extrinsic (death receptor) pathways, which converge to activate a caspase cascade. The caspases involved in apoptosis include initiator caspases (8, 9 & 10) and executioner caspases (3, 6, & 7). The following image depicts the apoptotic pathway:



Necroptosis is a caspase-independent, programmed form of necrosis. It combines features of necrosis (ATP depletion, swelling, membrane rupture) with programmed regulation. It involves two kinases called receptor-interacting protein kinase 1 and 3 (RIPK1 and RIPK3)

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent pathway driven by lipid peroxidation. This disrupts membrane integrity and leads to cell death resembling necrosis.

questions.text: 10. A child presented with fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly. His father also has had a similar history. On peripheral smear, MCHC was found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with an increased MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) and a family history, are suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. 

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hereditary hemolytic anemia that is passed down in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations of the red blood cell surface proteins spectrin and ankyrin can result in unstable cell membranes, leading to hemolysis.

This disorder can present at a young age with severe jaundice and fatigue. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones. Hence, childhood gallstones should raise suspicion for this diagnosis.

The laboratory findings include normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is usually normal or slightly decreased, the mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is characteristically increased (>34 g/dL), and hematocrit is decreased due to hemolytic anemia.

The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor (shown in the image below). Osmotic fragility test, acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test help in diagnosing hereditary spherocytosis.

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy. However, due to the possible adverse effects, it is only indicated in severe cases and after the child attains puberty in moderate cases. It should be followed up with the appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.



Other options:

Option A: Thalassemia is a hereditary hemoglobinopathy resulting from deficient synthesis of one or more globin chains. It is associated with microcytic hypochromic anemia (low MCHC), typically with low MCV and MCH.

Option B: Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene, replacing glutamic acid with valine. This leads to polymerization of deoxygenated HbS and the formation of sickle-shaped RBCs.

Option D: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is due to antibody and complement-mediated destruction of RBCs. Diagnosis is confirmed using the Coombs test. The direct Coombs test detects antibodies bound to RBCs, while the indirect test identifies antibodies in the serum.

Pearl PM1247: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune


2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

* Mechanical injury

* Trauma caused by cardiac valves 

* Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 

* Repetitive physical trauma

* Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)

* Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility

* Transfusion reaction  

* Drug-induced 

* Infections of red blood cells 

* Malaria

* Babesiosis

* Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

* Hereditary spherocytosis

* Thalassemia

* Sickle cell anemia

* Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

* G6PD deficiency

* Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: 11. A 60-year-old man presents with weakness, fatigue, and bleeding tendencies. His peripheral smear showed 25% blast-like cells, as shown in the image. What is the most common type of genetic abnormality seen in this hematological malignancy?
questions.solution:
A peripheral blood smear revealing 25% blast-like cells along with prominent faggot cells (blast cells containing multiple Auer rods) strongly points towards acute myeloid leukemia (AML) subtype M3, also known as acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The most common genetic association with this leukemia is t(15;17), resulting in a PML-RARA fusion gene.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a malignancy of hematopoietic progenitor cells with impaired differentiation, causing accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the bone marrow. This replacement of normal blast cells in the marrow leads to anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia, along with their associated clinical manifestations. Anemia causes weakness and fatigue, thrombocytopenia increases bleeding tendencies, and neutropenia predisposes to fever and infections.

In AML-M3, the malignant cells release large quantities of procoagulants and fibrinolytic factors that can cause disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and further increase the bleeding tendency. This subtype of AML can be treated with targeted therapy that uses all-trans retinoic acid and arsenic salts. They have the best prognosis among different subtypes of AML and a high cure rate.

The following image demonstrates typical myeloblasts containing Auer rods as seen in acute myeloid leukemia.



Other options:

Option A: inv(16) or inversion 16 is typically observed in acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AML-M4).

Option B: t(8;21) is characteristic of AML with maturation (AML-M2).

Option C: AML with NPM1 is recognized as a distinct entity per the WHO classification that shows normal cytogenetics with the NPM1 gene mutation.

Pearl PM1998: Important Translocations in AML

Translocation t(8,21)

(most common) 

 t(15,17) t(16,16) or inv(16)
Fusion gene

RUNX1-RUNX1T1

 PML-RARα CBF-β (Core binding factor)
FAB classification

Blasts with maturation/M2

 Acute promyelocytic leukemia/M3 Myelomonocytic/M4
Clinical association Myeloid sarcoma/ chloroma DIC Eosinophilia
Prognosis Good Very good Good


Pearl PM1244: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

* Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion

* AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion

* AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion

* AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion

* AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion

* AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion

* AML with KMT2A rearrangement*

* AML with MECOM rearrangement

* AML with NUP98 rearrangement

* AML with NPM1 mutation

* AML with CEBPA mutation

* AML, myelodysplasia-related#

* AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

* AML with minimal differentiation

* AML without maturation

* AML with maturation

* Acute basophilic leukaemia

* Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia

* Acute monocytic leukaemia

* Acute erythroid leukaemia

* Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: 12. A 6-month-old infant presents with recurrent infections and failure to thrive. Laboratory investigations reveal decreased B cells, T cells, and a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA). Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders is most likely associated?
questions.solution:
Recurrent infections, failure to thrive, decreased B-cell and T-cells, along with the deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA), are suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

SCID affects both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses, primarily impacting T cells and resulting in the absence or severe underdevelopment of lymphoid tissues like lymph nodes and tonsils. The thymus biopsy shows remnants of Hassall's corpuscles. 

Affected children present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive. Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including: 

* Candida albicans

* Pneumocystis jiroveci

* Pseudomonas

* Cytomegalovirus

* Varicella

There are two main types of SCID:

* X-linked SCID: The most common form, caused by a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. This leads to reduced T-cell numbers and impaired antibody synthesis despite normal B-cell counts. The thymus shows undifferentiated epithelial cells.

* Autosomal recessive SCID: Often due to ADA deficiency, causing toxic metabolite accumulation that damages T cells, resulting in greater T-cell reduction. Other, less common autosomal recessive causes of SCID involve RAG and JAK3 mutations.

In both forms, the thymus is small and lacks lymphoid cells, but ADA deficiency uniquely features remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles.

Other options: 

Option A: Hypogammaglobulinemia is characterized by reduced immunoglobulin levels, affecting humoral immunity. Transient hypogammaglobulinemia can occur in children under 6 months of age and is marked by low IgG levels. This condition typically resolves after 6 months of age.

Option B: DiGeorge syndrome results from a deletion of chromosome 22q11, leading to loss of T cell-mediated immunity. Its characteristic features can be remembered by the mnemonic CATCH-22: Cardiac abnormalities, abnormal facies, thymic aplasia, cleft palate, and hypocalcemia. The absence of the thymus in this condition causes recurrent infections.

Option D: Alpha-1 antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by protein misfolding that impairs the secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. This condition affects the liver and the lungs.

Pearl PM0536: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text:
13. A 45-year-old man with midline neck swelling presented with odynophagia and dyspnea. The swelling showed cells with variations in size and morphology. Amyloid deposit was also seen. The swelling was positive for IHC markers TTF-1, synaptophysin, and chromogranin. What is the diagnosis?

IHC - Immunohistochemistry
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, along with biopsy showing amyloid deposits and positivity for TTF1, synaptophysin, and chromogranin, is suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid arises from the parafollicular C cells. Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests, trabeculae, or follicles. Amyloid deposits, derived from altered calcitonin molecules, are present in the stroma. Calcitonin can be readily demonstrated in tumor cells and the stroma by immunohistochemistry.

Features of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid include:

* Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy

* Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion

* Diarrhea due to increased intestinal motility (VIP secretion)

* Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production

* Blood-borne metastases

Diagnosis is established by careful family history, physical examination, elevated calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid can be associated with RET gene (chromosome 10) mutations in cases of MEN-2A and MEN-2B syndromes. 

The following image shows the histopathological slide of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid:



Other options:

Option A: Papillary thyroid carcinoma shows papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei. Psammoma bodies, a form of dystrophic calcification, are its microscopic hallmark.



Option C: Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized histologically by uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid, resembling a normal thyroid gland, or sheets of cells without colloid.



Option D: Undifferentiated (anaplastic) carcinoma of the thyroid displays varied morphology with giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both, minimal follicular differentiation, and intratumoral necrosis.

questions.text:
14. A young patient presented with PND, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. However, the patient succumbed to her illness. On autopsy, the lungs showed hemosiderin-laden macrophages. In which of the following can it occur except:

PND - Paroxysmal Nocturnal Dyspnea
questions.solution:
The above clinical case describes heart failure cells, which are intra-alveolar hemosiderin-laden macrophages that indicate chronic passive congestion of the lung leading to pulmonary edema. These cells are not seen in protein-losing enteropathy.

In chronic pulmonary congestion, red blood cells leak from the engorged alveolar capillaries into the alveoli, where they are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages. Within these macrophages, hemoglobin is broken down, leading to the accumulation of brown hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm. Because of their strong association with pulmonary congestion in congestive heart failure (CHF), these macrophages are called heart failure cells. The following image shows heart failure cells:



Protein-losing enteropathy causes excessive protein loss, leading to reduced intravascular oncotic pressure. This results in fluid shifting into the extravascular spaces, producing ascites, pleural effusion, or pericardial effusion. Occurrence of pulmonary edema is uncommon, and therefore it is not associated with heart failure cells. 

Other options:

Option A: Right heart failure most commonly develops as a consequence of left heart failure, where ↑ Left Ventricular End-Diastolic Pressure (LVEDP) → ↑ Left Atrial Pressure (LAP) → ↑ Pulmonary Venous Pressure. This venous congestion results in pulmonary edema and the appearance of heart failure cells.

Option C and D: Pulmonary venous obstruction and volume overload can both produce chronic passive congestion of the lungs, resulting in pulmonary edema and the presence of heart failure cells.

questions.text: 15. Which of the following diseases is shown by the pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
The given pedigree chart is indicative of the Mitochondrial pattern of inheritance, and Kearns-Sayre syndrome is an example of mitochondrial inheritance.

Mitochondrial inheritance:

* Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum), as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.

* Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease, while an affected father cannot transmit it, and the mother passes it on to all her offspring.

80% of mitochondrial DNA codes for mitochondrial RNA, and therefore most mitochondrial DNA mutations lead to functional problems, which may be manifested as muscle disorders.

Kearns–Sayre syndrome (KSS) is characterized by progressive external ophthalmoplegia (PEO), pigmentary retinopathy, and cardiac conduction defects, most often heart block. The disease typically presents before the age of 20 years and may be associated with cerebellar ataxia, progressive myopathy, cognitive decline, and elevated CSF protein levels. A distinctive feature of KSS is white matter disease related to cerebral folate deficiency. It is usually a sporadic disorder caused by mitochondrial DNA deletions.

Other options:

Option A: Prader-Willi Syndrome is a genetic disorder due to an imprinting defect involving the paternal chromosome 15.

Option B: Achondroplasia is an Autosomal Dominant condition caused due to a mutation in the FGFR3 gene.

Option D: Williams Syndrome is mostly sporadic, but the inherited cases follow an Autosomal Dominant pattern of inheritance.

Pearl PM2375: Diseases of mitochondrial inheritance



* Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome

* Inherited exclusively from the affected mother

* These diseases include: (mnemonic: KLMNOP)

Disease

K: Kearn- Sayre Syndrome (KSS)

Ophthalmoplegia

Pigmentary retinopathy

Cardiomyopathy

L: Leigh disease

Subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy

Some have white matter lesions

M: MELAS

Mitochondrial myopathy

Encephalopathy

Stroke-like episodes

(MERRF) Myoclonic epilepsy, ragged red fibers in muscle, ataxia, sensorineural deafness

N: NARP (2 clinical patterns)

1. Neuropathy, ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, dementia

2. Severe infantile encephalopathy with lesions in basal ganglia

O: Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)

Ophthalmoplegia

Cardiomyopathy

Diabetes
